_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Lykes Meat Group, Inc, is complying with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Regulation, Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations, (CFR)1910.119, and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Mananagement Program (RMP) Regulations, Title 40 Code of the Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68.  These Regulations deal with the risk involved with the storage, handling and processing of hazardous chemicals.  In complying this way, we promote overall facility, employee, and public safety.  Lykes Meat Group's Program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence of, and minimize the consequences of, significant releses of toxic sustances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs are in place to prevent the potential for accidental injury, illness, death, and to avoid the potential for property and environmental damage.
Lykes Meat Group's safety programs are applied to all activitiesss involving hazardous chemicals including use, storage, handling, or the onsite movement of chemicals.  Any group of vessels interconnected and separate vessels which are located such that a hazard chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a singel process.
Lykes Meat Group's prevents accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures , and best practices which govern processes, activites, and or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and revies as necessary.  All information is communicated to employesss of Lykes Meat Group, Inc. through training and documentation.
In Worst Case Scenario, failure of the high pressure reciever under worst case weather conditions would release approximately 12,623 pounds of ammonia over a 10 minutes period.  The relase would travel up to 1.42 miles before no longer posing a significat hazard to the public.  However, this scenario is highlhy unlikely fo

r the following reasons:

Worst Case weather condition are uncommon?.
Th vessel is in a protected area clear of vehicular and redestrian traffic..
Industry standards for the construction and quality control of pressure vessells?
Safety relief valves preventing over-pressurization of the vessel are in use?
Accident prevetion programs are in place?
Mechanical integrity program, inspection and testing procedures are in place?
Emergency alerting alarms intergrated in to the process system?
Emergency response and action plans in place at the faciltiy?

In an alternative case scenario, leak around 3" flange gasket of the reciever of approximately 3,650 pounds of ammonia over a ten minute period before no longer posing a significant threat or hazard.  The vapor could travel as far as 0.25 miles.  Mechanical deterioration of the an ammonia pump seal was chosen as an alternative release because of its hight likelihood that it could occur.  This scenario evern though potentially possiible, is unlikely for the following reasons:

Emergency shut-down procedures?
Regular Maintenance?
Inspection and rounds made daily of the process systems to ensure safe operations?
Emergency response plan and refrigeration personnel on-site around the clock?

Lykes Meat Group's accidental release prevention program's are based on safe work practices as referenced by the  OSHA, EPA American National Safety Standards and the Inter national Institue of Ammonia Refrigeration 2-1992. Key elements of this prevention program are comprised of :

Equipement design, installation, and operation of ammonia process systems (ANSI/IIAR 2 )?
Emergency Response and Action Plan Program (OSHA 29CFR1910.120, 1910.38, and EPA 40 CFRR Part 68) ?
Mechanical integrity, Emergency shutdown procedures and inspection program (OSHA 29CFR 1910.119).

Lykes Meat Group has expirenced no accidental releases in the past five years.

The facility emergency response program is based on OSHA's Regulation for Emergency Action Plant

(1910.38 & 1910.119) and HAZWOPER (29 CFR1910.129).  Lykes Meat Group, Inc. has an onswite trained emergency response team (HAZMAT) and maintains a written emergency response plan which is reviewed annually.  This plan is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee, Fire Department, Police, and Emergency Medical facilities to ensure communication with all potential or actual included resources should their involvement be necessatated by a release.
Through Process Hazard Analysis, inspections, annual reviews and audits, Lykes Meat Group, Inc. Continuosusly improves it?s process system, proceduresm, programs and training to ensure mitigation, control, technology, equipment, and organizational changes remain consistent and in force.  Throug hthis initative, Lykes Meat Group, Inc. can ensure the utmost safeguards are utilized as it relates to it's process system and programs for the overall safety and well being of the employees, facility and the environment.
